image.caption: Collection of the U.S. House of Representatives

profileText: A Representative from North Carolina; born in Patetown Community, March 24, 1943; attended public schools; A.B., University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill, N.C., 1965; J.D., University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill, N.C., 1967; United States Navy, 1967-1970; United States Air Force Reserve, 1970-1983; United States Navy Reserve, 1983-1993; commenced the practice of law in Goldsboro in 1970; member of the North Carolina state house of representatives, 1978-1986; special advisor to President William J. Clinton, 1995; Assistant Secretary of the Army, 1996-1997; president, North Carolina Community College System, 1997- present; elected as a Democrat to the One Hundredth and to the three succeeding Congresses (January 3, 1987-January 3, 1995); unsuccessful candidate for reelection to the One Hundred Fourth Congress in 1994.

researchRecord.name: 1971-1994, 82.5 linear feet.
researchRecord.description: The papers document H. Martin Lancaster's tenure in the North Carolina General Assembly and in the United States House of Representatives. The papers include legislative materials (bills, committee reports, etc.) and correspondence relating to the issues discussed in the legislative materials. About 20% of the collection relates to H. Martin Lancaster's tenure in the North Carolina House of Representatives, 1978-1986. The rest of the collection relates to H. Martin Lancaster's time in the United States Congress as a Representative from the Third North Carolina District, 1987-1994. A finding aid is available in the repository and online.

recordLocation.name: Southern Historical Collection, The Wilson Library

parentRecordLocation.name: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill Library

researchRecord.name: 1986-1990, 2 videocassettes.
researchRecord.description: The videocassettes include 8 commercials used during H. Martin Lancaster's campaigns for the 1986 and 1990 U.S. congressional elections in District 3 of North Carolina, Democratic Party.

recordLocation.name: The Julian P. Kanter Political Commercial Archive, Department of Communication
